journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Engineering, The British University in Dubai, United Arab Emirates

author-notes.corresp: Alaa A-Ameer, Faculty of Engineering, The British University in Dubai, PO Box 345015, Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Email: alaa.ameer@buid.ac.ae

abstract.p: The modelling of a dual gas turbine, single-shaft transmission drive, for a naval propulsion system, is considered. Owing to the spatial dispersion of the arrangement, a distributed–lumped parameter approach to the dynamic analysis problem is necessary. This enables the relatively concentrated assemblies to be included as lumped, pointwise representations and the propulsion shaft to be incorporated as a dispersed inertia and stiffness element. A multivariable, least effort controller design strategy is employed to achieve the regulation required. The performance of the closed-loop system following reference input and load disturbances is evaluated and the drive shaft speed and twist angle response transients are computed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Power transmission systems often employ two prime movers for purposes of operational efficiency. Typically, low- and high-power engines/motors may be used to accommodate widely varying load conditions whilst minimising energy dissipation, cost expenditure and emissions. A wide variety of applications including hybrid internal combustion/electric motor drives, warship cruise and manoeuvring gas turbine (GT) propulsion and diesel–electric power transmissions may be configured in this way.

Often a single prime mover is used to obtain the required driving torque, with some form of automatic transfer to the low- or high-power unit following load changes. As a consequence, during high-speed operations, the high-power prime mover provides the whole of the traction with the remaining unit either remaining idle, or passively motoring on the drive shaft.

In principle, both units could be used to provide the maximum torque requirement in these applications. However, the difficult issue of load sharing between the two prime movers must then be addressed.

This consideration is complicated owing to the changing speed demands on the system and stochastic loading disturbances, both of which prevail throughout operational duty cycles. The use of epicyclic gearing and/or power electronics may be used to adjust dynamic loading imbalances. However, these are costly solutions which also attract substantial increases in complexity and mass/inertia, as significant penalties.

An alternative approach would be to treat the tandem, power transmission design problem as a directly coupled drive with the use of multivariable feedback, as in Dutton et al.1 to enforce the required speed/torque and shaft twist regulation.

An appropriate control strategy here would be to simultaneously regulate the transmission shaft speed and twist angle outputs, with both engines/motors supplying power. This would lead to both drive units operating in concert, in accordance with all loading and speed changes, without the use of complicated electronic switching or gearing.

In the design, the employment of an accurate drive shaft model for the naval propulsion application under consideration is necessary. Essentially, the spatial dispersion of this element will be included in the modelling and regulator design exercise, as in Bartlett and Whalley.2

The shaft forward and stern end twist angle difference, required in the feedback regulation system, could be provided by strain gauge measurements with electrical signal transmission, via shaft-mounted slip rings. Alternatively, speed transducers and integration could be used for this purpose, as shown herein.

Equally, to ensure cost-effective, efficient implementation a least effort multivariable design strategy will be adopted. This procedure uses only passive control elements whilst minimising the generation of heat, wear and operating costs providing thereby the efficient regulation required, for successful implementation.

The naval applications included in this submission are particularly important. Effectively, the propulsion system proposed would allow single and/or dual drive configurations with the GT unit or units operating at near to full load efficiency. This would avoid the fuel-expensive, part-load performance, exhibited by GT drive systems which have restricted applicability.

sec.title: System model
sec.p:
In this exercise, the dual GT drive system, shown in Figure 1, will be considered. All the inertias and frictional coefficients for the GT engines are referred to the main drive shaft, as in Patel and Munto.3 The prime mover inertia and combustion dynamic effects can be represented by simple, exponential delays and gain terms, as in Whalley and Ebrahimi.4,5 Figure 1.
Dual gas turbine propulsion system.

If the drive shaft is modelled as a distributed parameter element, as shown in Appendix 2, and if each prime mover rotational inertia and gearing is represented by lumped inertias, at each end of the drive shaft, then the Laplace transformed model for this system, with torque inputs T1(s) and T2(s), is (1)[T1(s)-T2(s)]=[ζ1w1(s)+γ1(s)-ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)1/2ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)1/2-ζ1w1(s)-γ2(s)] ×[ω1(s)ω2(s)] In equation (1) γ1(s)=J1s+c1,γ2(s)=J2s+c2 and if L1=ρ1Js and C1=1(G1Js) then ζ1=L1C1=Js(ρ1G1) Also (2)w1(s)=e2l1Γ1(s)+1e2l1Γ1(s)-1 where in equation (2) Γ1(s)=sL1C1=sρ1/G1 Then, following the inversion of equation (1) (3)[ω1(s)ω2(s)]=[ζ1w1(s)+γ2(s)ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)12ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)12ζ1w1(s)+γ1(s)]Δ(s)[T1(s)T2(s)] where in equation (3) Δ(s)=ζ1(γ1(s)+γ2(s))w1(s)+γ1(s)γ2(s)+ζ1 2 and in delay form since (4)w1(s)=(1+e-2l1Γ1(s))(1-e-2l1Γ1(s)) then (5)(w1 2(s)-1)12=2e-l1Γ1(s)(1-e-2l1Γ1(s)) With the inclusion of the GT fuel pump and combustion dynamics, see for example Winterbone et al.,6 of approximately (6)T1(s)=g1v1(s)(τ1s+1) and (7)T2(s)=g2v2(s)(τ2s+1) the distributed–lumped system model becomes, in terms of percentage input and output changes (8)[ω1(s)ω2(s)]≅[ζ1w1(s)+γ2(s)ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)12ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)12ζ1w1(s)+γ1(s)]Δ(s) ×[g1τ1s+100g2τ2s+1][v1(s)v2(s)] Hence (9)(ω1(s),ω2(s))T=Gs(s)(v1(s),v2(s))T In this application, the prime mover time constants are approximately equal. Hence, if τ1=τ2=τ=0.05s and if the power gain of the high-power unit is approximately twice that of the low-power unit, then in equation (9) (10)Gs(s)=g1[ζ1w1(s)+γ2(s)2ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)12ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)122ζ1w1(s)+γ1(s)]Δ(s)(τs+1) where in equation 10, g1 is the torque-speed gain.

sec.title: System model transformation, scaling and open loop response
sec.p: In order to regulate shaft speed in this application, a control strategy aimed at attaining a cooperative power drive wherein the GT respond in concert, to achieve the demanded outputs required. To do this, the outputs to be controlled could be selected as the shaft twist angle ϕ(s) and the shaft speed ω2(s). A transformation of the system model, given by equation (9), is necessary to achieve this.

Since φ(s)=(ω1(s)-ω2(s))s then (11)(φ(s),ω2(s))T=N(s)Gs(s)(v1(s),v2(s))T where in equation (11) for percentage input and output changes N(s)=[θs-θs01] where θ=100/φmax(s), where here the design limit for φmax(s)=0.1rad and since v1max(s)=v2max(s)=100V and a 1% voltage change results in a 1% torque change then g1 = 1, in equation (10), for perturbed changes.
Also, ω1max(s)=ω2max(s)≅100rad/s, with normal operational speed limited to 50% maximum in this naval propulsion application.

With this transformation, the output response from equation (11), following input step changes of 1%, are shown in Figure 2(a) and (b) and Figure 3(a) and (b), for the parameter values given in section ‘Application study’. The block diagram representation for the open-loop system is as shown in Figure 4. Figure 2.
(a) Open-loop % change in shaft angular velocity following 1% change in v1(t). (b) Open-loop % change in shaft twist angle following 1% change in v1(t). Figure 3.
(a) Open-loop % change in shaft angular velocity following 1% change in v2(t). (b) Open-loop % change in shaft twist angle following 1% change in v2(t). Figure 4.
Open-loop system block diagram.

sec.title: Closed loop strategy
sec.p: In the design procedure outlined herein, an outer loop and pre-compensator will, primarily, be employed to secure specified steady state, reference set point and low frequency, disturbance rejection and output response conditions. An inner loop will be utilised, to attain initial, targeted, dynamic and load disturbance recovery rates, with the system equation (12)y(s)=G(s)u(s)+δ(s) where in equation (12) G(s)=N(s)Gs(s) The control law for the proposed configuration is (13)u(s)=k(s)(r¯(s)-h(s)y(s))+P(r(s)-Fy(s)) where in equations (12) and (13), there are m independent inputs, disturbances and outputs and F=Diag(f1,f2,…,fm),0<fj<1, 1≤j≤m With r¯(s)=0, the closed-loop equation becomes (14)y(s)=(Im+G(s)(k(s)><h(s)+PF))-1 (G(s)P>r(s)+δ(s))
If a steady-state matrix Ss is now selected such that y(0)=Ssr(0) then from equation (14) with δ(s) null (15)P=(G(0)-1+k(0)><h(0))Ss(Im-FSs)-1
Substitution for P from equation (15) results in equation (14) becoming, with Ss≅Im,at low frequencies (16)fteqaligny(s)= {Im+G(s)[k(s)><h(s) +(G(0)-1+k(s)><h(s))(Im-F)-1F]}-1 ×{G(s)P>r(s)+δ(s)}
As shown in Appendix 2 and in Whalley and Ebrahimi,7 if F=diag(f,f,…,f) G(s)P≅11-f(Im+G(s)k(0)><h(0))

Consequently, equation (16), on approaching steady-state conditions becomes (17)y(s)=Imr(s)+S(s)δ(s) where in equation (17) the low-frequency sensitivity matrix is S(s)=(1-f)(Im+G(s)k(s)><h(s))-1, 0<f<1.0
Evidently, as: f is increased, 0<f<1, there would be increasing steady-state disturbance rejection, under stable operating conditions.

The forward path K(s) and feedback path compensator H(s) required, for implementation purposes, can easily be computed from the closed-loop equation (18)y(s)=(Im+G(s)K(s)H(s))-1[GK(s)r(s)+δ(s)] Comparing equations (14) and (18) evidently (19)K(s)=P And (20)H(s)=P-1k(s)><h(s)+F enabling the employment of established, feedback structures.

sec.title: Inner loop analysis
sec.p: The Laplace transformed open-loop description, given by equation (12), where the system model G(s) is assumed to be an m × m linear, regular, proper or strictly proper realisation, admits a factorisation (21)G(s)=L(s)A(s)d(s)R(s)Γ(s) where L(s),A(s),R(s),G(s)and>the>elements>of A(s)d(s)∈H∞,s∈

In equation (21), L(s) contains the left (row) factors, R(s) contains the right (column) factors and Γ(s) contains the transformed, actuator finite-time delays of G(s) and A(s) is a non-singular matrix of rational functions, such that det A(s) ≠ 0, with elements (22)aij(s)=aijsm-1+bijsm-2+…+γij, 1≤i and j≤m

Since the transformed input–output–disturbance relationship is (23)y(s)=G(s)u(s)+δ(s) and if the inner loop control law is (24)u(s)=k(s)[r¯(s)-h(s)y(s)] then combining equation (22) and (24) yields (25)y(s)=(Im+G(s)k(s)><h(s))-1(G(s)k(s)r¯(s)+δ(s)) The finite time delays in Γ(s) may be ordered with T¯i≥T¯j,1≤j≤m i≠j so that the forward path gain vector can be arranged as (26)k(s)=[k1(s)e-s(T¯i-T¯1),k2(s)e-s(T¯i-T¯2),…,×ki(s),…,km(s)e-s(T¯i-T¯m)]T and since (27)h(s)=(h1(s),h2(s)…hm(s)) then if kj(s)=kjφj(s)andhj(s)=hjχj(s)1≤j≤m where ϕj(s) and χj(s) are proper or strictly proper, stable, realisable, minimum phase, functions then they may be selected such that equation (25) becomes (28)y(s)=(Im+e-sT¯in(s)L(s)A(s)d(s)k><h)-1 (n(s)L(s)A(s)d(s)ke-sT¯ir(s)+δ(s)) where in equation (28) (29)k=(k1,k2…km)T and (30)h=(h1,h2…hm)d(s)=sκ+a1sκ-1+…a0 and deg (n(s)ai,j(s)) < κ, 1 ≤ i, j ≤ m
The determinant required in equation (28) is (31)det[Im+e-sT¯in(s)L(s)A(s)d(s)k><h] =1+e-sT¯in(s)<hA(s)d(s)k>

The inner product in equation (31) may be expressed as (32)〈h mathvariant="bold">A(s)k〉=[1,s,…sm-1][γ11γ12…γmm:::b11b12…bmma11a12…amm][k1h1k2h1:kmhm] when A(s) contains rational functions of s. Otherwise, the vector [1,s,…,,sm-1] may be replaced by a vector of irrational terms or any combination of rational and irrational functions may be employed, as herein.

If in equation (32) the gain ratios are (33)k2=n1k1,k3=n2k1,…,km=nm-1k1 and if (34)áhA(s)kñ=λ(s) then equation (34) implies that (35)k1[Q(n)]h=(λm-1,λm-2,…,λ0)Tg1 where in equation (35) Q(n)=[γ11+γ12n1+…γ1mnm-1:γ21+γ22n1+…γ2mnm-1:γm1+γm2n1…+γmmnm-1:::::b11+b12n1+…b1mnm-1:b21+b22n1+…b2mnm-1:bm1+bm2n1…+ammnm-1a11+a12n1+…a1mnm-1:a21+a22n1+…a2mnm-1:am1+am2n1…+ammnm-1]

and; λj,0≤j≤m-1, are the coefficients of λ(s), given in equation (34). Providing the weak constraint, that n1,n2,…,nm-1 can be selected in equation (35) so that the matrix is invertible, then a unique solution for (h1,h2,…,hm)g1 exists.

Following the choice of a suitable λ(s) function and the gain ratios n1,n2,…,nm-1 the closed-loop dynamics arising from equation (28) are fully defined. Upon solving equation (35) the measurement vector h can be evaluated once an arbitrary value for k1 has been decided upon.

The inner loop design procedure is equally valid for non-square system models. To achieve an optimum, least effort, controller design, the choice of the gain ratios n1,n2,…,nm-1 should be in accordance with the theoretical procedures of Appendix 3.

sec.title: Inner-loop design for distributed–lumped GT drive model
sec.p:
The inner loop control law from equation (24), for this application is (36)(v1(s),v2(s))T=k(s)(r¯(s)-h¯(s)(φ(s),ω2(s))T) and the block diagram representation is shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Inner-loop block diagram.
Hence (37)(φ(s),ω2(s))T=(I2+N(s)Gs(s)k(s)><h¯(s))-1 N(s)Gs(s)k(s)r¯(s)
In equation (37) the determinant required is (38)det(I2+N(s)Gs(s)k(s)><h¯(s))= 1+<[103h1(s),(sh2(s)-103h1(s))]G(s)k(s)s>

The inner product, in equation (38), may be written as (39)υ(s)[Φ(s)(k1h¯1,k2h¯1,k1h¯2,k2h¯2)T-I3λ]=0 where in equation (39) h¯1=103h1(s) and h¯2=sh2(s)-103h1(s)υ(s)=[(w1 2(s)-1)1/2,s,1](s(τs+1)Δ(s)) λ=(λ1,λ2,λ3)Tg1 is the multiplier for υ(s) and: Φ(s)=[ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)1/2w1(s)2ζ1ζ1ζ1(w1 2(s)-1)1/2w1(s)J2002J1c2+ζ1w1(s)002(c1+ζ1w1(s))] Putting: k2=nk1 and with the low-frequency condition that (w1 2(s)-1)1/2w1(s)=1, 1w1(s)=0, then since υ(s)≠0, in equation (39) (40)[ζ1+2nζ1ζ1+2nζ1J22J1nc22c1n][h¯1h¯2]=[λ1λ2λ3]g1 where in equation (40) the coefficients λ1, λ2 and λ3 become the weights for the characteristic equation (41)1+υ(s)λ=0
The solution for the first two equations, of equation (40) is (42)[h¯1h¯2]=[2J1n-(ζ1+2nζ1)-J2ζ1+2nζ1](ζ1+2nζ1)[2J1n-J2][λ1λ2]g1

so that since J1 and J2 are very small, in comparison to ζ1 then (43)[103h1(s)sh2(s)-103h1]=[-λ1λ2]g1(2J1n-J2) and λ3 can be calculated following the establishment of h1(s) and h2(s) to satisfy the third equation of equation (40). The simplest solution here would be to let: λ1=λ2=λ,in equation (43) so that sh2(s) would be zero and (44)h1(s)=-λg110-3(2J1n-J2)

sec.title: Optimisation analysis and stability assessment
sec.p: Although the gain ratio n, in equation (39), may be selected arbitrarily, the analysis of Appendix 3, to achieve the optimum, least effort controller, requires the minimisation of the functional (45)J=λT(Q-1(n))TQ-1(n)λ where in equation (45) λ=(λ1,λ2,λ3)Tg1 and from comparing equations (35) and (42) Q(n)=[ζ1+2nζ1ζ1+2nζ1J22J1n]
Since for a particular application J1,J2 and ζ1, of Q(n), will be known, the minimisation of the J functional enables the gain ratio n, where k2=nk1, to be determined from the optimisation process.

Consequently, the relative stability condition for the inner loop can now be assessed from equation (41) which results in (46)(λ1(w1 2(s)-1)12+λ2s+λ3)g1(s(τs+1)Δ(s))≠-1 In the frequency domain, with s = iω the function of equation (46) must leave the −1,0 point to the left for 0<ω<∞ since this system is open-loop stable.

sec.title: Application study
sec.p: In this illustrative application study, a naval propulsion system which has a drive shaft of length l, with polar second moment of area of Js,will be considered. The arrangement of the system is as shown in Figure 1, where there are relatively lumped inertias and bearing frictions, referred to the shaft, at the stern and at the forward end. The system parameters are J1=6.0×10-2kgm2,Js(shaft)=0.61359×10-6m4,J2=15.0×10-2kgm2,c1=0.5,c2=20Nm>s/rad,l1=4.0m,d=0.05m,G1=80×109N/m2,ρ1=7800kg/m3,m=2 From these values, as shown by equation (2) (47)ζ1=Js(ρ1G1)=15.3275 (48)Γ1(s)=s(ρ1G1)=(3.122499×10-4)s

The time constant τ of the prime movers for illustration purposes is (49)τ=0.05,γ1(s)=J1s+c1 and γ2(s)=J2s+c2 The first step in the design procedure is to establish the inner, closed-loop controller details, as this loop is used to adjust the system dynamics, to improve the speed of response. The calculation for the optimum gain ratio n can be determined from equation (45) which when evaluate for this system becomes (50)J=λT(Q-1(n))TQ-1(n)λJ=[(1+n2)(λg1)2×10-6](12n-15)2×10-4

The graph of function (50) is shown in Figure 6, where g1 which does not affect the value of n minimising J, has been included as unity. Clearly, the minimum value of J occurs when n = n1 where: (51)n=-0.8 With this value of n and following the substitution of J1,J2,c1andc2,with the selection of λ=λ1=λ2, to simplify the inner-loop feedback, equation (42) results in λ3g1=c2h¯1+2c1nh¯2λ3=4.06λ Hence, the υ(s)λ function is (52)υ(s)λ=λg1((w1 2(s)-1)12+s+3.03¯)(s(τs+1)Δ(s)) where Δ(s) is given by equation (3) and the Nyquist diagram from equation (52) is shown in Figure 7, giving conservative gain and phase margins, acknowledging thereby the inclusion of the finite time delays for λg1 = 1000 Figure 6.
Performance index J against n. Figure 7.
Nyquist design for inner-loop characteristic equation.
From equation (43) h2=0 and h1 = 4.06 and since n = -0.8,ifk1=1,k2=-0.8, as in equation (33)
This concludes the inner-loop design.

To complete the outer-loop design, the pre-compensator P must be computed in accordance with equation (15). In this case, in equation (12) G(0)=N(s)Gs(s)|s→0 and with an initial selection of a steady-state matrix to allow 0.1% steady-state output coupling Ss=[10.10.11] and since k=(1,-0.8)Th=(4.06,0) then P=[(N(s)G(s)|s→0+k(0)><h(0))Ss(I2-FSs)] may be computed for several values of: F=fI2,0<f<1.

Using L’Hopital’s theorem,8 evaluation yields N(s)G(s)|s→0=[0.0794-0.00380.04880.0975] so that for f = 0.7 P=[54.73651.6288-31.519333.3727], for example. Figure 8 shows the final closed-loop configuration for analysis purposes. Figure 8.
Closed-loop configuration for analysis.

For implementation purposes, a conventional pre and feedback compensator structure may now be determined, in accordance with equations (19) and (20). Hence K(s)=P and for f = 0.7 H(s)=[P-1[1-0.8][4.060]+0.7I2]=[0.77630-0.0270.7]

Figure 9 shows the general structure for this system where some economy in terms of testing, tuning and commissioning may be achieved with this compact arrangement. Figure 9.
Closed-loop block diagram for implementation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: To demonstrate effectiveness the performance of the closed-loop system following a reference input step change on the speed demand r2(t) will be investigated, for three values of outer loop gain, f = 0.7, 0.8 and 0.9. Thereafter, for the same values of outer-loop gain, the disturbance suppression and recovery characteristics of the system will be determined, with the imposition of step disturbances on the shaft angular velocity output ω2(t).

In Figures 10 and 11, the response of the system following reference input, step changes on r2(t) are shown. Figure 10 exhibits well behaved, monotonic transients with the speed of response improving, for increasing values of outer loop feedback gain, f. The distributed parameter shaft dynamics are shown in Figure 11, where the oscillatory, shaft twist angle characteristics increase substantially, as f increases, with rising energy transmission and hence shaft torsional, transient excitation. Figure 10.
%Change in shaft angular velocity following a 1% step input reference change on r2 (t). Figure 11.
%Change in shaft twist angle following a 1% step input reference change on r2 (t).

In Figures 12 and 13, the fuel flow change to the forward and stern GT engines, respectively, are shown following a step demand on r2(t). Here, the stern end GT is shown to support the major part of the load change with the forward end GT, containing the shaft twist angle by executing the high-frequency oscillations depicted in Figure 12, allowing the smooth power transition, illustrated by Figure 10. Figure 12.
%Change in fuel flow to Fwd End GT following a 1% step input reference change on r2 (t). Figure 13.
%Change in fuel flow to stern end GT following a 1% step input reference change on r2 (t).

The disturbance suppression performance of the system is also pleasing, as shown in Figure 14 where the system off-set is reduce with increasing values of outer-loop gain f. Figure 15 indicates that the shaft twist angle change reduces to zero within approximately 0.5 s with a similar build-up of oscillatory behaviour, to that exhibited following reference input signal changes. Figure 14.
%Change in shaft angular velocity following a 1% step disturbance change on shaft velocity ω2(t). Figure 15.
%Change in shaft twist angle following a 1% step disturbance change on shaft velocity ω2(t).

To counter load changes, Figure 16 shows that there is a permanent increase in fuel flow to the forward end GT. Equally, Figure 17 shows a permanent increase in fuel flow to the stern end GT without the rapid transient excitation which the smaller, forward end GT exhibits. Figure 16.
%Change in fuel flow to Fwd End GT following a 1% step disturbance change on shaft velocity ω2(t). Figure 17.
%Change in fuel flow to stern end GT following a 1% step disturbance change on shaft velocity ω2(t).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this contribution, the problem of regulating two, directly coupled prime movers, on a single drive shaft was considered. Owing to the spatial dispersion of the system, the drive shaft was modelled as a distributed parameter element, whilst the prime movers could be adequately described by simple delay, lumped parameter models.

The difficulty in operating with tandem drives is that imbalance often occurs with one prime mover ‘motoring’ on the drive shaft. For this reason, separate low- and high-power systems are usually used. In particular, in warship applications the high-power system is usually provided by large capacity GT units, driving the port and starboard shafts, respectively, whilst the smaller cruise drive may employ engines of less than 50% of this capacity.

This arrangement also allows the high and/or cruise engines to be operated at near to full load avoiding thereby the extremely poor, part-load, fuel efficiency rating of GT. Importantly, the frugal use of fuel would maximise the hazardous evolution of ‘replenishment at sea’, extending thereby the range and flexibility of warship deployments.

However, as shown herein, the initial analysis reflects the complexity of the situation with the system input–output matrix model exhibiting numerical singularity at low frequencies and with extremely small, model determinant values at all frequencies.

This arises from the rigidity of the shaft model and from the elementary observation that the steady-state running speed, at each end of the shaft, is identical. To overcome this design difficulty, a transformation was proposed enabling the basic model to be used to compute shaft twist, as well as the stern end shaft speed. This system shaft speed and twist angle, matrix model is well posed (regular) enabling the prediction of steady-state conditions in the design/analysis exercise.

In particular, the requirement for both speed and twist angle control could now be accommodated within the inner and outer loop design structure employed, for least effort regulation. The inputs could also be coupled if desired, so that a demanded speed change would automatically allow a prescribed increase in the steady-state shaft twist angle, in accordance with normal running conditions.

Following the least effort design procedure, the computed response predictions for step input changes, on the shaft speed, reference input, were shown to illustrate effectiveness. The regulated response of the system, as shown from the transients, improved without exciting non-minimum phase transients, overshoot or settling time problems.

With dynamic compensators and increasing loop gains further improvements in the system behaviour could be affected. However, the principle concern was to achieve least effort control with the use of simple proportional gain terms whilst accommodating the distributed parameter shaft and hybrid, high integrity, system model.

Finally, the focus of the study should be remembered in that this viability exercise, was mainly concerned with the desirability of employing a tandem drive, rather than separate low- and high-power propulsion units. As shown herein, this is achievable providing accurate modelling and an efficient feedback regulation strategy is imposed.

This gives the clearly identifiable advantages demonstrated. These include improvements in steady state and dynamic performance, operating efficiency, capital expenditure, compactness, reduced maintenance cost and manning levels, all of which are important in naval operations.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors wish to acknowledge the receipt of funding from the British University in Dubai, UAE.

ref.citation: DuttonKThompsonSBaracloughR. The art of control engineering. Harlow: Addison Wesley, 1997.
BartlettHWhalleyR. Power transmission system modelling. Proc IMechE Part C J Mech Eng, 1998; 212: 497–508.
PatelRVMunroN. Multivariable system theory and design, Vol. 4. International Series on Systems and Control, Oxford: Pergamon Press, 1984.
WhalleyREbrahimiM. Automotive gas turbine regulation. IEEE Trans Control System Tech 2004; 12(4): 465–473.
WhalleyREbrahimiM. Gas turbine propulsion plant control. ASNE Nav Eng J 2002; 114(4): 77–94.
Winterbone DE, Munro N and Lountie PMG. Design of a multivariable controller for an automotive gas turbine. In ASME gas turbine conference, Washington, 1973.
WhalleyREbrahimiM. Multivariable system regulation. Proc IMechE Part C J Mech Eng 2006; 220: 653–666.
BradieB. Numerical analysis. NJ: Pearson Int. Inc, 2006.

def.p: shaft material equivalent compliance per meter =1/GJs scalar
shaft second moment of area scalar
polar moment of inertia of rotors scalar
inner product of vectors k and h scalar
outer product of vectors k and h matrix
forward GT combustion and fuel gain and time constant scalar
stern GT combustion and fuel gain and time constant scalar
shaft material equivalent inductance per meter =ρsJs scalar
number of inputs and outputs scalar
forward GT fuel pump motor voltage scalar
stern GT fuel pump motor voltage scalar
lumped inertia and damping function, function

sec.title: The torsional response for a distributed parameter shaft model
sec.p: In the following derivation, a distributed parameter shaft, in torsion, of length l, with diameter d will be considered. The shaft comprises an infinite series of infinitesimal elements dx which are subjected, at a distance x along the shaft, to torque inputs and outputs of T(t,x) and T(t,x+dx), respectively.

The corresponding angular velocity, inputs and outputs, are ω(t,dx) and ω(t,x+dx), respectively. Each element has an associated series inductance L which is equivalent to the shaft’s inertia per unit length. A shunt capacitance C, equivalent to the shaft’s compliance per unit length, is also acknowledged. The internal friction of the shaft material will be assumed to be small enough to neglect enabling all frictional dissipation to be seen as originating from the bearings and windage alone.
Hence L=ρπd4/32 (shaft inertia/m) C=1/GJs (shaft compliance/m)

For analysis purposes, the shaft consists of an infinite series of elements, as shown in Figure 18. Figure 18.
Incremental shaft element.

The governing equations are (53)T(t,x+dx)-T(t,x)=-L∂ω∂t(t,x+dx)dx (54)ω(t,x+dx)-ω(t,x)=-C∂T∂t(t,x+dx)dx In the limit as dx→0, equations (53) and (54) become (55)∂T(t,x)∂x=-L∂ω(t,x)∂t (56)∂ω(t,x)∂x=-C∂T(t,x)∂t Following Laplace transformation, with respect to time, with zero initial conditions, equations (55) and (56) may be written as (57)dTdx=-Lsω (58)dωdx=-CsT where in equations (57) and (58) T=T(s,x)andω=ω(s,x) Differentiating with respect to x enables equations (57) and (58) to be written in the form d2Tdx2=-Lsdωdxandd2ωdx2=-CsdTdx Hence (59)d2Tdx2=LCs2T and (60)d2ωdx2=LCs2ω Equations (59) and (60) have the same form and identical general solutions.

If a propagation function is defined as Γ(s)=sLC then the general solutions required are (61)T(s,x)=AcoshΓ(s)x+BsinhΓ(s)x (62)ω(s,x)=C¯sinhΓ(s)x+DcoshΓ(s)x when x = 0 A=T(s,0),D=ω(s,0) Differentiating equations (61) and (62) with respect to x and equating to (57) and (58) gives: (63)-Lsω(s,x)=AΓ(s)sinhΓ(s)x+BΓ(s)coshΓ(s)x (64)-Csω(s,x)=C¯Γ(s)coshΓ(s)x+DΓ(s)sinhΓ(s)x Equation (63) with x = 0 becomes -Lsω(s,0)=BΓ(s) so that (65)B=(-LsΓ(s))ω(s,0)=-LCω(s,0) If the characteristic impedance is defined as ζ=LC then, from equations (65) and (66) B=-ζω(s,0) and C¯=-ζ-1T(s,0) Hence, equation (61) and (62) become (66)T(s,x)=coshΓ(s)xT(s,0)-ζsinhΓ(s)xω(s,0)ω(s,x)=-ζ-1sinhΓ(s)xT(s,0)+coshΓ(s)xω(s,0) At distance l along the shaft: (67)[T(s,0)ω(s,0)]=[lcoshΓ(s)-ζlsinhΓ(s)-ζ-1lsinhΓ(s)lcoshΓ(s)][T(s,0)ω(s,0)] Equation (67) can be arranged in impedance form as (68)[T(s,l)T(s,0)]=[-ζlctnhΓ(s)ζlcschΓ(s)-ζlcschΓ(s)ζlctnhΓ(s)][ω(s,l)ω(s,0)] where ctnhΓ(s)l=(e2Γ(s)l+1)(e2Γ(s)l-1)=w(s) and since cshΓ(s)l=(ctnh2Γ(s)l-1)1/2=(w2(s)-1)1/2 with this notation equation (58) becomes T(s,0)=T1(s),T(s,l)=T2(s)ω(s,0)=ω1(s)andω(s,l)=ω2(s) Hence, for a torque input T1(s) and a torque output T2(s) (69)[T1(s)T2(s)]=[ζw(s)-ζ(w2(s)-1)1/2ζ(w2(s)-1)1/2-ζw(s)][ω1(s)ω2(s)]

sec.title: Optimisation
sec.p: The possibility of optimising the inner-loop gain ratios n1,n2…nm-1 of equation (35) can now be considered. An indication that the freedom exists to do this arises from the arbitrary choice of the values of n1, n2 etc. Detecting the absolute, minimum control effort required for disturbance suppression, under closed-loop conditions, with the constraint that the controller model generates a particular polynomial, would provide a useful, optimisation, benchmark. This polynomial influences the migration pattern of the closed-loop poles so that control effort minimisation to disturbances and the desired, inner loop, system response to input changes could be achieved simultaneously. The controller equation for a system having m inputs and m outputs is given by equation (24).

Hence, the control energy costs, under these conditions, are proportional to (70)E(t)=∫t=0 t=Tf(∑i=1 mki 2∑j=1 mhj 2yj(t)2)dt then for arbitrary changes in the transformed output vector y(t), following arbitrary disturbance changes, minimising (71)J=∑i=1 mki2∑j=1 mhj2 would minimise the control energy required, given by expression (70). If the relationships k2=n1k1,k3=n2k1,…,km=nm-1k1, are adopted, then equation (71) can be written as (72)J=(k1)2(1+n1 2+n2 2…nm-1 2)(h1 2+h2 2…hm 2) and h1 2+h2 2…hm 2=áh,hTñ. The closed-loop determinant is given by equation (31) with the inner product equated to λ, the coefficients of λ(s), as in equation (34), then from equation (35) (73)hT=k1 -1Q-1λg
Upon substituting for h from equation (73), equation (72) becomes with g1 = 1, since this does not affect the extremum values (74)J=(1+n1 2+n2 2+…nm-1 2)λT(Q-1)TQ-1λ
To find the minimum value for J, assuming, for example, that m = 3 gives J=(1+n1 2+n2 2)λT(Q-1)TQ-1λ where J is minimised when ∂J∂n1=0,∂J∂n2=0 and> ∂2J∂n1 2∂2J∂n2 2-(∂2J∂n1∂n2)2>0, if∂2J∂n1 2>0

For m > 3, a numerical optimisation routine could to be employed to establish the values of n1,n2…nm-1 which minimise J. There are many procedures available for this task with rapid convergence and high-accuracy characteristics.
This completes the inner loop analysis.
